Group.title: Updating Software
Group.description:
The yum command line tool is used to install and update software packages. Yum replaces the up2date utility used in previous system releases. The system also provides two graphical package managers, pirut and pup. The pirut tool is a graphical front-end for yum that allows users to install and update packages while pup is a simple update tool for packages that are already installed. In the Applications menu, pirut is labeled Add/Remove Software and pup is labeled Software Updater.
It is recommended that these tools be used to keep systems up to date with the latest security patches.

Rule.title: Ensure Red Hat GPG Key Installed
Rule.description: To ensure that the system can cryptographically verify update packages (and connect to the Red Hat Network to receive them if desired), run the following command to verify that the system has the Red Hat GPG key properly installed: $ rpm -q --queryformat "%{SUMMARY}\n" gpg-pubkey The command should return the string: gpg(Red Hat, Inc. (release key <security@redhat.com>)
Rule.rationale: This key is necessary to cryptographically verify that packages are from Red Hat.

Rule.title: Disable rhnsd Service
Rule.description: The rhnsd daemon polls the Red Hat Network web site for scheduled actions. Unless needed, it is recommended that the service be disabled with the following command: #chkconfig rhnsd off
Rule.rationale: This utility is not required for the system to be able to access and install system updates. The service should be disabled if there is no need for the system to run actions scheduled through RHN.

Rule.title: Ensure Software Patches Installed
Rule.description: The following command prints a list of packages that need to be updated: # yum check-update To actually install these updates, run: # yum update
Rule.rationale: Installing software updates is a fundamental mitigation against the exploitation of publicly-known vulnerabilities.

Rule.title: Ensure "gpgcheck" Enabled In Yum Configuration
Rule.description:
The gpgcheck option should be used to ensure that checking of an RPM packageâ€™s signature always occurs prior to its installation.
To force yum to check package signatures before installing them, ensure that the following line appears in /etc/yum.conf in the [main] section: gpgcheck=1
Rule.rationale: Ensuring the validity of packages' cryptographic signatures prior to installation ensures the provenance of the software and protects against malicious tampering.

Rule.title: Ensure "gpgcheck" Enabled For All Yum Package Repositories
Rule.description: To ensure that signature checking is not disabled for any repos, ensure that the following line DOES NOT appear in any repo configuration files in /etc/yum.repos.d or elsewhere: gpgcheck=0
Rule.rationale: Ensuring that all packages' cryptographic signatures are valid prior to installation ensures the provenance of the software and protects against malicious tampering.
